question: Damage to which area of the brain can cause alexia and agraphia?

A 30-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of loss of pain and temperature sensations in the right arm. He has a history of gunshot wounds to the left side of the spinal cord. Where is the lesion located?
What is the mechanism of action of benzodiazepines?

answers.option: Blocks T-Type Ca 2+ channels in thalamic neurons
Facilitates GABA-A action by increasing frequency of Cl- channel opening

question: A 40-year-old married man presents to the emergency room with coarse tremors and visual hallucinations. He is unable to identify his family members. When asked about the time of the day he gives an incorrect answer. He also gives vague answers on the hospital whereabouts. Detailed history reveals regular and heavy alcohol intake for the last 10 years. On examination his pulse is 100/min, blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg and respiratory rate of 32 per min. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 19-year-old male is brought by his father to the psychiatry clinic with complaints of singing out loud throughout the night, sleeplessness, and claiming he is a famous singer. He had one similar episode in the past and one previous episode with symptoms of low energy and mood, for which he received treatment and reached a pre-morbid level of functionality. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old male, with a history of hypertension and diabetes, is brought to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset left-sided weakness for the last 1 hour. On examination, his blood pressure is 220/110 mm Hg, his pulse is regular at 90 beats/min, and his GCS is 12/15. He has left-sided hemiparesis with upgoing plantars. CT scan of the brain reveals no findings. All baseline investigations are also within normal limits. What should be the first step in the management of this case?

An 81-year-old female comes to the neurology outpatient department with complaints of diminished facial expression (often termed masked facies), stooped posture, slowing of voluntary movement, taking progressively shortened, accelerated steps, rigidity, and a “pill-rolling” tremor. The first gene to be identified as a cause of Parkinson's Disease encodes a-synuclein, an abundant lipid-binding protein normally associated with synapses. Mutations in alpha-synuclein take the form of point mutations and amplification of the region of chromosome 4q21 that contains the gene. What is the mode of inheritance of these genes?

A brain tumor histopathology specimen shows cells with round nuclei with clear cytoplasm (fried egg appearance) associated with dystrophic calcification. What is the most likely brain tumor that exhibits these features?
A brain histopathology specimen shows pale substantia nigra and locus ceruleus with neuronal achromasia, tangles, and ballooned neurons. Which of the following diseases exhibits these features?

A 68-year-old male patient requires pharmacological treatment for Parkinson disease. He has a past medical history of benign prostatic hyperplasia and chronic constipation. Which of the following drugs should not be used in this patient?
Which drug is suitable for the treatment of malignant hyperthermia?
Which of the following anti-depressants has a stronger risk of self-harm and suicide?
Which of the following is a common variable used for a pie chart?

A 16-year-old girl is brought by her mother to the psychiatry clinic with concerns regarding her behavior for 2 weeks. She has stopped going to school and stays in her room the entire day. She refuses to eat food and claims that it has been poisoned. She also believes that her family has installed cameras in her room to keep a close eye on her. She has stopped interacting with her friends and family. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with a complaint of anosmia for 5 months. Radiological imaging shows a mass in the anterior cranial fossa along the olfactory groove. A primary brain tumor is suspected. What is the cell of origin of the most likely tumor?

A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with weakness in his upper and lower limbs after falling from a height. The weakness is more in the upper limbs than the lower limbs. Which type of spinal cord injury is most likely responsible for this presentation?
Which of the following options include all four cardinal symptoms that are present in Parkinson disease?

answers.option: Tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability
Tremor, bradycardia, rigidity, and postural instability

question: A 66-year-old male complains of progressive problems with gait, speech, and hand tremors for two years. He also has occasional lightheadedness with standing and a 6-year history of impotence. He has no past medical history and takes no medications. His blood pressure is 140/84 mm Hg lying down, and 98/72 mm Hg standing, without change in pulse. Mental status is normal. He has reduced facial expression, high-pitched dysarthria, and mild anterocollis. There is no resting tremor. He has an irregular tremulousness of both hands when outstretched, worse on the right, without ataxia on finger-to-nose testing. He is bradykinetic and his gait is slow, shuffling, and unsteady. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Compared to sporadic Parkinson disease (PD), PD that is due to a dominantly inherited mutation in the a-synuclein gene is characterized by which of the following?

answers.option: The stronger association with neuromuscular junction dysfunction
Older age at the onset of symptoms
More robust response to dopaminergic therapy

question: Which of the following is the most common brain tumor in children occurring in the posterior cranial fossa?

A 40-year-old female presents with right-sided unilateral headaches for the past 5 months. Physical examination yields no remarkable findings. The representative gross appearance of the lesion seen on the CT scan of the head shows a dura-based mass. Surgical removal and microscopic examination show elongated cells with pale, oblong nuclei and pink cytoplasm with occasional psammoma bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is considered a subset of a population?
How soon after a stroke should rehabilitation be initiated?
Which of the disease-modifying medications used for multiple sclerosis (MS) is administered via the intramuscular route?
Which of the following is an absolute contraindication of central axial block?

A politician intends to implement a primary prevention program against neurological diseases in the area. Which of the following measures would be appropriate as a primary prevention in the community?

A group of students used an analysis of variance test (ANOVA) to test the hypothesis that the mean systolic blood pressure among various ethnicities is different. In the first step of ANOVA, they obtained an F-statistic less than the critical value. What would be the second step considering their analysis is correct?

answers.option: Report the results as it is

question: A student compares the body weights of a group of 100 children before and after four weeks of nutrition supplementation for his research project. His hypothesis is: "the nutrition supplementation brings a change in the body weights of children". He uses an independent sample t-test for his hypothesis testing and finds highly significant results at a p-value of 0.001. His professor checks his report and rejects it. Which of the following assumptions must have been violated?

answers.option: Independence of observations should be there
The dependent variable should be categorical
Independent variable should consist of three categories
The dependent variable should be skewed
There should be more significant outliers

question: A lecturer is teaching epidemiological study designs to his students. He emphasizes the follow-up data of the patients and how to reduce the loss of follow-up in an observational study design. The professor is teaching which of the following epidemiological study designs to his students?

A group of students was conducting a research study to find out the risk factors of stomach cancer in Karachi city. They had a limited budget and time to complete this study on a rare disease such as stomach cancer. Which of the following epidemiological study designs would be appropriate to fulfill their study objectives?

A group of researchers was conducting a study on the relationship of high dose vitamin D on stomach cancer 5-year survival outcome. They identified 100 stomach cancer patients and randomly allocated 50 patients to vitamin D and the other 50 to the placebo through a coin toss. The above statement refers to which of the following study designs?

While working in the health office of district Thatta a student came across several cases of oral cancers from 10 talukas. The student also had data on the number of gutka outlets in different talukas. He wanted to find an association between the number of persons affected and gutka sales in the area. What would be the most appropriate study design?
A medical student wants to find the prevalence of coronary heart disease among adult males in the district central of Karachi. Which epidemiological study design is most appropriate for this study?

Qualitative data does not have quantitative x and y observations for each participant so the relationship between two variables cannot be computed by correlation coefficient. For example: the frequency of males smoking versus females smoking. Which one of the following tests can be performed to see the association between two variables in such situations?

A survey of 100 men and 100 women revealed that 15 of the men and 36 of the women were overweight. The chi-square test of significance was applied to find an association at alpha equal to 0.05. Which one of the following options contains the correct decision if the calculated value for Chi is greater than the Chi critical?

answers.option: Fail to accept the alternate hypothesis

question: Which of the following steps should be avoided while giving first aid to the victim of a snake bite?

answers.option: Removing any items or clothing which may constrict the bitten area
Incision or suction of venom from bitten area
Cleaning the wound area with water

question: The snake venom can cause damage to multiple systems of the body depending upon the type of snake venom injected by the snake bite. A bite may also trigger a potentially fatal anaphylactic reaction. The manifestations of local pain, redness, swelling, and extravasation of blood are mostly in envenomation by which of the following snakes?
A consultant asked a medical student to assess a patient on a Glasgow coma scale in the emergency department. This scale generally assesses which of the following?

A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed as a case of Parkinson's disease in the neurology outpatient department. The neurophysician suggested levodopa for his disease-related symptoms. Which of the following statements is true about the mechanism of action of levodopa?

answers.option: Levodopa is directly converted into dopamine in the periphery
Levodopa is converted into dopamine by dopa decarboxylase in the brain
Levodopa is hydroxylated into the chemical compound in the brain

question: Which of the following statements is the most accurate regarding the drugs used for the treatment of Parkinson disease?

answers.option: Therapeutic effects of amantadine continue for several years
The benefit of antimuscarinic drugs in Parkinson's disease is to relieve bradykinesia
Selegiline is a selective COMT inhibitor (catechol-o-methyl transferase inhibitor)
Dopamine receptor agonists should never be used in Parkinson's disease before the trial of levodopa
Levodopa causes mydriasis and may precipitate an acute attack of glaucoma

question: Which of the following is a troublesome adverse effect of levodopa when used for Parkinson disease?

A male patient reported to the psychiatric clinic for his psychiatric problem. He was prescribed lithium for his mental issues. Which of the following is the most accurate for the clinical indication of lithium?
Haloperidol is not a suitable option for the treatment of which of the following psychiatric conditions?
A 30-year-old male office worker suffers from intense migraine headaches. Which of the following drugs is a serotonin 5-HT (1D/1B) agonist useful for decreasing an acute migraine headache?
A 51-year-old woman presents with symptoms of major depression and closed-angle glaucoma. Which of the following antidepressants needs to be avoided in this patient?

A 23-year-old patient with a history of severe postoperative nausea and vomiting comes for plastic surgery. Which of the following anesthetic drugs would be best to use for maintenance in this situation?

A 33-year-old female patient needs to be anesthetized before dilation and curettage for abnormal uterine bleeding. Her anesthesia is induced initially with an inhaled nonflammable anesthetic that contains no halogenated carbons. Which of the following agents best fits this description?

A 19-year-old man has a 4-cm laceration of the palmar aspect of his hand. The wound needs to be sutured with absorbable sutures. Before beginning the procedure, the wound is injected with lidocaine containing 1:100,000 parts epinephrine. The rationale behind the use of epinephrine is which of the following?

answers.option: Releases nitric oxide from the vessels
Increase bleeding to improve toxin release from the wound
Vasodilation at the side of administration

question: A 7-year-old female is diagnosed with absence seizures by a neurophysician. Which of the following drugs will be most appropriate to prescribe as a drug of first choice for treating her seizures?
Which of the following is a very potent and short-acting benzodiazepine when used as a hypnotic causes psychiatric disturbances in some cases?
Coadministration of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) with which one of the following drugs may induce a central serotonin syndrome?
Which of the following monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) is most likely to produce a cheese reaction?
Which of the following antidepressant drugs affect dopamine reuptake?

A first-year anesthesiology resident reaches for isoflurane as the induction agent for a patient who is about to receive general anesthesia. When the attending faculty sees this, he quickly takes the syringe away from the resident because this agent can cause which of the following effects when used for induction?
A 70-year-old patient in the intensive care unit needs sedation due to prolonged endotracheal intubation. Which of the following medications should be avoided for sedation in this patient?

A 35-year-old male patient presents with appendicitis and requires a surgical intervention. He has a family history of malignant hyperthermia. Which anesthetic agent is the most appropriate to use in this patient?

A 78-year-old male patient with a long history of seizure disorder controlled with phenytoin presents to his dentist for routine follow-up. Which of the following findings must the dentist be concerned about and evaluate for?
A case of morphine poisoning is diagnosed in the medical emergency department. Which of the following drugs shall be given to reverse morphine intoxication in this patient?

A young male patient suffers from a seizure disorder characterized by tonic rigidity of the extremities followed by 15 to 30 seconds of tremor progressing to massive jerking of the body. This clonic phase lasts for 1 to 2 minutes, leaving the patient in a stuporous state. Which of the following drugs would be most suitable for the long-term management of this patient?

A 2-month-old male child presents with a history of progressively enlarging head size since birth. His fontanelles are bulging and tense. Which of the following is true regarding the production of CSF?

answers.option: A major source of production of cerebrospinal fluid is the ependymal lining
It is absorbed by the arachnoid granulation
It is produced by the dura mater
Normally turnover of cerebrospinal fluid is 72 times a day
The normal rate of production is 50 milliliters per hour

question: A 38-year-old male presented with complaints of intermittent headaches and drop attacks. Investigation reveals a colloid cyst in the ventricles causing hydrocephalus. This type of hydrocephalus is known as which of the following?

A 45-year-old male presents in the emergency room after a road traffic accident with complaints of vomiting and headache. Glasgow coma scale (GCS) shows M6 E4 V4. Pupils are anisocoric and reactive. A computed tomography (CT) scan reveals a biconvex hyperdensity over the right temporoparietal region along with a fracture of the temporal bone. The sensory level is at the umbilicus. What is the most likely source of blood?

A 50-year-old male presents in the emergency room after a road traffic accident with an altered level of consciousness and vomiting. The patient has abnormal flexion in pain and opens his eyes in pain with no verbal response. Pupils are equal and reactive. A computed tomography (CT) scan reveals a crescent hyperdensity over the right frontoparietal region along with a midline shift. What is the total Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score of the patient?

A 60-year-old male presents with a history of a fall, complaining of neck pain and difficulty in doing normal house activities. On examination, he has weakness and sensory disturbance more in the upper limbs than in the lower limbs. What kind of spinal cord injury does he have?

A young soldier on the field had a gunshot injury on his back. On examination, he had paralysis of the right leg, loss of proprioception and fine discrimination of the right leg, and loss of pain and temperature in the left leg. What kind of spinal cord injury he had?

A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency room with sustained head trauma after which he developed a headache and bleeding from his right ear. A computed tomography (CT) scan shows a right temporal bone fracture. He is managed and discharged home after a period of observation. One week later he comes with difficulty in closing his right eye. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?

A 27-year-old nurse presented with occupational dysfunction and loss of interest in her hobbies for 2 months. She was convinced that she would not be able to work again nor would pursue her hobbies of trekking and painting. Recently, she broke up a relationship with her husband. She thought that her life was not worth living and had consumed 60 tablets of phenobarbitone to end her life. She is most likely suffering from which of the following?

A 26-year-old female is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of aggression, over-talkativeness, hyperactivity, and decreased sleep for one week. Her family reveals that she has had two similar episodes in the past 3 years, for which she received treatment. A diagnosis of bipolar affective disorder with a current episode of mania was made. Which of the following groups of medications would be suitable for treatment in this case?

A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of restlessness, sweating, tachycardia, and difficulty in breathing for 1 month. These symptoms are episodic. There is a family history of hypertension. Laboratory investigation shows a normal level of vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) in urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 25-year-old woman suffers from insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. She has been thoroughly informed on how to use insulin and what her diet should be. Furthermore, she is an intelligent girl who understands all of this. Nonetheless, at times, she secretly stops her insulin for no clear external gain like missing a test, and takes in too many carbohydrate-containing foods and drinks that necessitate emergency treatment. Because this behavior is secretive, her doctors wonder what they are doing wrong regarding her treatment. The patient herself seems very forgiving, tells them that she knows they are doing their best, and seems to enjoy the attention of doctors and nurses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this case?

A 27-year-old electrical engineer is brought to the psychiatric unit involuntarily by his friend, who found a handwritten note in his apartment expressing feelings of hopelessness and despair, suggesting he might be contemplating ending his life. He recently lost his job and going through a crisis in his family. Which of the following is the most appropriate management step for this patient?

answers.option: Assess the capacity of the patient

question: A 25-month-old boy is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of being unable to walk. The father gave a history of delayed crying and was born with obstructed labor. On examination, he has increased tone and power of 2/5 in all four limbs. Which of the following is the most severe form of the above-mentioned disease?

A 3-year-old, partially vaccinated boy presented with acute onset of fever with inability to walk because of weakness in both feet. Weakness progressed over 2 days to involve the whole of both lower limbs. On examination, he was conscious but anxious and irritable. Vitals were normal. He had hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and power of grade 2/5 in both lower limbs with mute planters and intact sensations. Upper limbs and cranial nerves were intact. What would be the most appropriate test to confirm the most likely diagnosis?

answers.option: Two stool samples, 24 to 48 hours apart for viral isolation
Stool for viral isolation 48 hours after the onset of weakness

question: A 2-year-old boy presented to the emergency room with a complaint of fever for 2 days and seizure for 30 minutes, 4 hours back. His temperature was 38°C. On examination, the throat was congested, and the central nervous system (CNS) examination was normal. What would be the most probable diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy was suffering from high-grade fever, cough, and runny nose for 3 days. Early in the morning, he developed right-sided focal fits involving the right arm, followed by unconsciousness for a few hours. Upon awakening, he was unable to move his right arm and right leg and had a left-sided facial palsy of the lower half. What would be the most likely cause of his condition?

A 35-year-old clerk who lives in a slum area of Sindh, presented in the emergency department with low-grade fever, headache, and irritability for 2 months and one episode of uprolling of eyes, jerking of limbs, and incontinence of urine one day back. He had a history of chronic productive cough for six months. On examination, his Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score was 10/15 and he had bilateral papilledema. Which best possible treatment regimen would be appropriate to start?

answers.option: Anti-tuberculosis therapy, steroids, and anti-seizure drugs

question: A 70-year-old male patient presented to the neurology outpatient department with complaints of slowness of walking and abnormal movements of hands for two years. On examination, the attending physician noted bradykinesia, postural instability, and resting tremors in both hands. The tremors were more pronounced in the left hand. What is the typical frequency of tremors in this case?

A 35-year-old female was referred to a tertiary care hospital with an hour history of sudden onset right-sided hemiplegia and aphasia. Her national institutes of health stroke scale (NIHSS) score was 20. The on-call neurologist was on board for consideration of an intravenous tissue plasminogen activator. He asked his junior to generate radiology requests immediately from the emergency department. Which specific imaging modality would be considered in this case?

answers.option: Computed tomography (CT) scan brain with contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain and magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA)
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain and magnetic resonance venography (MRV)

question: A 30-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with complaints of difficulty in climbing the stairs and holding heavy objects in her hands for 4 months. It was associated with significant weight loss, dry cough, and muscle pain for 6 months. On examination, he was pale and febrile with generalized wasting. Proximal muscle powers were 3/5 with intact reflexes and downgoing plantar. Sensory examination was normal. What would be most likely seen on his muscle biopsy?

A 35-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of sequential complete loss of vision in both eyes over one week. He had a history of both lower limb weakness 6 months back with minimal recovery despite taking treatment. On examination, he had no light perception in both eyes with bilateral pale disc. There was spastic quadriparesis with sensory level at the xiphisternum. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 78-year-old otherwise healthy male is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of increasing forgetfulness, subtle behavioral changes, and difficulty in managing home finances for 6 months. On examination, he is vitally stable and his mini-mental state examination (MMSE) score is 22/30. All other neurological examinations are normal. Which of the following are the initial and most common presenting symptoms of the suspected illness?

A 56-year-old female presented to the neurology outpatient department with complaints of multiple neurological symptoms that suddenly appeared two days ago. Her magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain showed an infarct in the left lateral medulla. Which of the following would most likely be present in this patient?

A 52-year-old diabetic man presents to the emergency room with complaints of right-sided weakness and inability to speak for one hour. Acute stroke treatment is planned for him. What is the immediate target to save this patient?

A 27-year-old female presents to the emergency room with complaints of high-grade fever for one day and seizures for two hours. On examination, she has recurrent seizures, a fever of 103 degrees Fahrenheit, and a rigid neck. There is no focal weakness and both plantars are mute. Which of the following investigations has the highest diagnostic yield in this patient?

A 65-year-old gentleman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of twitching and wasting of his leg muscles for the last 2 years. He has also been experiencing progressive weakness in both lower limbs. He often chokes while drinking water and suddenly starts laughing without any reason. On examination, he has wasting and fasciculations in all four limbs with hyperreflexia and extensor plantar responses. What area of his nervous system is most likely affected?

An 11-year-old male student is sent home from school because he daydreams in class and does not pay attention. During the clinical consultation, he becomes unresponsive for about 10-15 seconds. He stares blankly off into space and then suddenly resumes talking. He has no recollection that anything abnormal has happened. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old female presents to the emergency room. She is a known case of epilepsy and has been on no treatment for the last 2 weeks. She has generalized tonic-clonic seizures which are continuous for the last 30 minutes. On arrival in the emergency room, her oxygen saturation is 70% on room air. Seizures stop spontaneously but the patient does not regain consciousness. On examination, she is not opening her eyes even to painful stimuli. She is localizing a painful stimulus with both hands. She is making grunting noises at intervals. What is the Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score of this patient?

A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. On examination, there is a clear sensory level at the T6 dermatome on the left side of the body. Below this level, there is a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left side and a loss of vibration and proprioception on the right side. Motor function is preserved on the right side but is impaired on the left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 20-year-old female presented with complaints of bilateral ptosis and fatigability for the last 2 years. After a clinical examination and confirmatory test, myasthenia gravis was diagnosed. Which of the following drugs would be safe to use?

A patient with Parkinson's disease presented at the rehabilitation medicine outpatient department for management. Which of the following statements is correct regarding rehabilitation management of Parkinson's disease?

answers.option: Auditory and visual queuing increase the risk of fall
The psychologist will give therapy to improve the activity of daily living (ADLs)
Exercise is harmful and increase the progress of disease
Increased weighted utensils and adaptive equipment will improve the activities of daily living (ADLs)
There are no rehabilitation management options available for Parkinson's disease

question: A 65-year-old male with a stroke presented to the rehabilitation outpatient department having left-sided hemiplegic and spastic gait. Which of the following orthosis is most commonly used to improve the gait of patients with stroke having spastic gait?

A 44-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with complaints of ascending weakness in all four limbs for 5 days. He was operated on for lumbar disc herniation 3 weeks back and became ambulatory within a week. On examination, he had grade 2/5 power in all four limbs with diminished reflexes and downgoing plantar. Which of the following investigation findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

A 6-year-old boy was brought to the outpatient department with complaints of frequent falls while running, and difficulty in rising from the ground. He had a positive family history of similar complaints. On examination, he was a young boy with an average build. Gait was lordotic. There was a scar mark over his right Achilles tendon. Powers were 4/5 in thigh muscles. Reflexes and sensations were normal. Which of the following is the most likely inheritance pattern of this disease?

An 18-year-old male presented with a history of frequent falls for the last two years. He had difficulty walking and due to imbalance became wheelchair-bound. He also had difficulty in carrying out daily household work describing a lack of precision. His family also noticed that his speech appeared to be drunken. He had no disturbance in memory and intellectual ability. His sister also had a similar illness. On examination, he had dysarthric speech, truncal ataxia, and bilateral upgoing planters with absent ankle reflex. Regarding the above clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male presented with complaints of left-sided facial pain involving half-face only. The pain was aggravated with eating, chewing, and shaving. The pain was sharp, stabbing, sudden, and current-like. No associated complaints of hearing loss and tinnitus were reported. Neurological examination was unremarkable. What would be the most likely diagnosis?

A spinal cord injury patient having C6 American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) impairment scale grade A, admitted to the ward suddenly complained of severe headache, flushing, dizziness, and disoriented. Her blood pressure was 160/100 mm Hg and her Foley catheter was clogged. What can be the most common diagnosis?

An 11-year-old girl presents with a history of increasing headaches upon awakening for the past month. On examination, papilledema is present bilaterally. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of her brain reveals a 3-cm solid circumscribed mass within the fourth ventricle. There is a third and lateral cerebral ventricular dilatation. The mass is excised and microscopically shows perivascular pseudorosettes with round, regular tumor cells arranged around vessels. Which of the following neoplasms is she most likely to have?

A 10-year-old boy presents with a complaint of persistent headaches for the past 3 months. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head shows a 4-centimeter cystic mass in the right cerebellar hemisphere. On gross examination, a cyst filled with gelatinous material. The cyst has a thin wall and a 1-centimeter mural nodule. Microscopically, the mass is composed of cells that have long, hair-like processes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 42-year-old male after a road traffic accident, suffered damage to the parietal lobe of his dominant hemisphere. What would be the most likely consequence?

A 32-year-old man was brought to the emergency room because he had been stabbed in the back during a fight and was bleeding profusely. He was taken for emergency surgery in the operating room. The surgeon realized that this patient had suffered a right lateral hemi-section of the spinal cord, at the level of C8, due to a stab wound. A brief physical examination of the patient was conducted when he arrived in the emergency room. What findings were most likely present in this patient?

answers.option: Spastic paralysis of the right lower limb
Spastic paralysis of the right lower face
Spastic paralysis of the left lower limb
Flaccid paralysis of the right lower limb
Spastic paralysis of the left upper limb

question: A neurologist while examining a 48-year-old patient noticed that he had lost the ability to discriminate between two points presented simultaneously on the skin of the left hand. Anatomically what is the most likely site of the lesion?

answers.option: Fasciculus cuneatus on the right side of the spinal cord at C2
Dorsal column on the right side of the spinal cord at T5
The spinothalamic tract on the left side of the spinal cord at C2
Fasciculus gracilis on the right side of the medulla
Medial lemniscus on the right side of the pons

question: A 39-year-old HIV-positive man has received no antiretroviral therapy. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head shows no intracranial hemorrhage, but there is a midline shift. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows a 4-centimeter circumscribed and solid mass. Cytologic examination shows large cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm that are marked with CD20, but not with glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) or cytokeratin. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old man was brought to the emergency room by his wife, as he developed difficulty in speaking and weakness in his right upper limb. However, he was able to understand what was being said to him. His symptoms began around 1 hour ago. His previous medical history was significant for hypertension for the past 18 years. After doing a physical examination on the patient, the doctor ordered a computed tomography (CT) scan of the head as his provisional diagnosis was that of stroke. Which vessel is most likely to be occluded in the patient?

Closed head injury resulting from an accident or cerebrovascular disease causing a stroke in the specific lobe of the brain may result in disruptions to social and emotional behavior. This can be produced by damage to which of the following?
Which of the following is an intravenous induction agent?
Which of the following intravenous induction agents cause pain during administration?
Which of the following is an ultra-short-acting opioid?
What are the structures that get pierced during spinal anesthesia?

answers.option: Ligament, ligamentum flavum, and dura mater
Skin, superficial fascia, and supraspinous muscle
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, and ligamentum flavum
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, and dura mater
Supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, and dura mater

question: In adults, the spinal cord extends to which of the following levels?
While transferring a patient through an air ambulance which of the following occurs due to high altitude?

answers.option: Low air in an endotracheal tube (ETT) cuff

question: According to the World Health Organization (WHO) pain relief ladder, moderate to severe pain should be treated with which of the following?
An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with or potential in terms of such damage is defined as which of the following?
A 25-year-old female planned for elective cesarian section. The patient is planned to proceed in central neuraxial blockade. It includes which of the following?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his parents. He has been complaining of headache, fever, and stiff neck for the past 2 days. He is also vomiting and has had no appetite. On physical examination, he is found to be febrile (102°F) and Kerning's sign is present. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. His computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain is normal. What investigation will be appropriate to perform to reach a diagnosis?

answers.option: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain with contrast

question: A 45-year-old man, a known case of diabetes with good glycemic control, was referred to the emergency room with a diagnosis of ischemic stroke. He developed weakness in his left upper and lower limbs 2 hours ago. His blood pressure was 130/80 mmHg and his blood sugar was normal. His computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain showed a right frontal infarct. He had no significant history. All laboratory investigations were normal. What would be the best treatment for this patient?
A young man is brought to the emergency room with a severe sudden headache within 2 hours after the onset. Which finding should be looked for in plain computed tomography (CT) brain?

answers.option: High density in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) spaces
Mixed high and low density in subcortical white matter

question: Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to treat gastroenteritis in a female patient with myasthenia gravis?

A 52-year-old woman comes to the sleep clinic for long-standing insomnia. She is prescribed a drug that modulates GABA receptors, lacks anticonvulsant or muscle-relaxing properties, and has minimal effect on REM sleep. Its actions are antagonized by flumazenil. Which of the following drugs is this?

A male patient comes to the outpatient department with bilateral lower motor neuron paralysis at the level of lesion, bilateral loss of pain, temperature, and light touch below the level of lesion, and bilateral spastic paralysis below the level of lesion. What will be the most likely diagnosis?

A patient with posterior cerebral artery stroke will present with which of the following?

A patient presents to the clinic with complaints of dysphonia, diplopia, nystagmus, a small pupil in the left eye, and inability to lift the left eyelid. He has loss of pain & temperature sensation on the left side of his face and the right side of his body. Which of the following arteries is most likely affected?
Which of the following is the most severe form of spinal dysraphism?
Spina bifida is caused due to the deficiency of which of the following?
A 10-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle weakness and red lesions on her eyelid and back. What would her muscle biopsy show?
When prescribing clozapine, which side effect is the most feared and should be closely monitored?
What is the most common side effect associated with sumatriptan?
Which of the following acts as an inverse agonist of the benzodiazepine receptor?
What is the recommended medication for the management of acute opioid poisoning?
Which psychoactive alkaloid is primarily responsible for the effects of marijuana?
Which finding on clinical examination would confirm the diagnosis of transverse myelitis?

answers.option: Loss of proprioception below a particular level
Loss of all sensation below a certain level
Muscle weakness on one side of the body
Decreased tactile sensation in a defined area

question: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with a sudden onset loss of vision, weakness, and paraparesis. A diagnosis was made of neuromyelitis optica affecting the dorsal columns, what would be observed on spinal MRI?

answers.option: Patchy changes in 1 to 2 spinal segments

question: A child presents to the clinic with fever and left leg paralysis. What is the appropriate investigation?
In a patient with a spinal cord injury at or above the T6 level presenting with hypertension in the upper body, what is the underlying cause of this phenomenon?
A patient presents with symptoms suggestive of raised intracranial pressure (ICP), what triad of clinical manifestations is typically observed?

answers.option: Fever, neck stiffness, altered mental status

question: Which of the following is seen in raised intracranial pressure (ICP)?

answers.option: Infratentorial lesions produce symptoms earlier than supratentorial lesions
Herniation of the temporal lobe causes third cranial nerve palsy

question: Which of the following is true about nitrous oxide?

answers.option: There is a direct association between the use of nitrous oxide and malignant hyperthermia
Anemia is a common adverse effect in patients exposed to nitrous oxide for periods longer than 2 hours
It is the most potent inhaled anesthetic
It is a useful component of anesthesia protocols because it lacks cardiovascular depression
Upto 50% of nitrous oxide is eliminated via hepatic metabolism

question: A doctor prescribes levodopa to his patient. Which of the following is important to know about the drug?

answers.option: Fluctuates in its effectiveness with increasing frequency as treatment continues
Prevents extrapyramidal adverse effects of antipsychotic drugs
Should be given in increased dosage if given together with a drug that inhibits hepatic dopa decarboxylase
Protects against cancer in patients with melanoma

question: A 51-year-old patient with parkinsonism is being maintained on levodopa-carbidopa with adjunctive use of low doses of tolcapone but continues to have off-periods of akinesia. Which drug will provide temporary relief?
What is the most common complication observed during rehabilitation in post-stroke patients due to faulty positioning?
What is the most commonly used drug for induction of general anesthesia?
A pregnant patient is allergic to procaine. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to give for epidural anesthesia?
Which of the following nerves is most likely to get injured during forceps delivery?
Which of the following is a risk factor for Parkinson's disease?
The researcher wanted to compare the difference in the mean blood glucose level of a group of 25 participants before and after meals. Which statistical test would be appropriate to use?
What is the best inhalational anesthetic agent for induction?

A 50-year-old farmer has been exhibiting agitated behavior for the past few weeks. He appears restless, irritable and increasingly withdrawn from his usual activities. Over the last day, he has refused to eat or drink anything and has shown resistance to going outside for fresh air, despite previously enjoying spending time outdoors. Additionally, he has developed some motor symptoms including muscle spasms. Based on the clinical presentation described, what is the likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old patient presents with recurrent seizures. On examination, there are no signs of meningeal irritation, and the patient's blood sugar level is within normal limits at 90 mg/dl. Imaging studies reveal abnormal findings in both temporal lobes. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

answers.option: Supportive care with hydration and monitoring

question: A middle-aged male presents with a diffuse headache that has persisted for a few weeks. The headache has a gradual onset and is associated with weight loss, anorexia, and pain on jaw movement. Upon fundoscopy, the only finding noted is a pale optic disc. How can a definite diagnosis be reached in this case?
A patient presents with ataxia along with a rash observed on the earlobes and conjunctiva. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 42-year-old female, a known case of multiple sclerosis for 5 years, presented with a complaint of fatigue. She has been taking teriflunomide for 3 years which resulted in complete remission. She was diagnosed with depression and prescribed fluoxetine 2 years back which managed her depression. What would be an appropriate treatment option for her fatigue?

What type of meningioma is characterized by a whorled continuous pattern of cells with psammoma calcifications, without distinct cell membranes?
What is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in a 22-year-old male?
A young child exhibits difficulty walking, spasticity in all four limbs, poor feeding, and delayed milestones. Which condition is most likely indicated?
An 18-year-old male with a history of delayed milestones and anoxia during birth exhibits difficulty walking properly. Which condition is most likely indicated?

A 5-year-old child presents to the outpatient department with loss of consciousness and a history of recurrent tonic-clonic convulsions over the past year. Birth and development were reported as normal. What is the likely diagnosis?

A child is brought unconscious to the emergency room with a history of seizures. The seizures started with twisting of the neck and eye deviation to one side, then progressing to jerky movements of all four limbs of the body. What is the true categorization of this seizure?
Which of the following is the safest approach for brachial block?

His blood pressure is 180/105 mmHg, the platelet count is 85,000/mm³, fever is 101°F, PT/INR is 1.6, and dengue NS1 antigen is positive. What represents an absolute contraindication to tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) administration?
Which of the following drugs is used for dissociative anesthesia?
A child is scheduled for an ENT surgery. Which potent local anesthetic with intrinsic vasoconstrictive effects is considered?
A student enters variables into the SPSS software, such as marital status and groups like medicine used/placebo. What type of variables are these?
What contributes significantly to the global burden of neurological disease?
More than half of the neurological burden in disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) is attributed to which of the following conditions?

A 45-year-old female patient who is a known case of an autoimmune disorder visits the neurology clinic with complaints of fatigue, tingling, numbness, muscle weakness, and muscle spasms. CSF analysis reveals oligoclonal bands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

answers.option: Tau protein aggregates in neurofibrillary tangles
Perivascular lymphocytes and demyelination of white matter
Loss of Purkinje cells in the cerebellum
Spongiform changes in the cerebral cortex

question: A woman who has been on medication for risk factors of ischemic heart disease (IHD) experiences leg cramps. Which drug has she been taking?

Which of the following statements is correct about stimulants?

answers.option: Amphetamine: decreases the release of catecholamines
Methylxanthine: acts as an agonist at dopamine receptors

question: What is the mechanism of action of carbamazepine?

answers.option: Facilitation of GABA actions on chloride ion channels

question: Which of the following drugs cause hirsutism, osteoporosis, and gingival hyperplasia?

answers.option: It is not contraindicated in pregnancy
Visual field defect is seen in 30% of patients

question: Which of the following exhibits neuropathy with autonomic features?

A patient comes to the clinic with a history of meningitis. He now complains of headaches and papilledema. What would be seen on a computed tomography (CT) scan?
A patient comes with complaints of difficulty in climbing stairs and walking, weight loss, low-grade fever, and solid cystic mass in the adnexa. What will be the most probable diagnosis?
Rehabilitation for stroke is initiated immediately after stroke. Which type of prevention is it?
Which type of prevention includes global polio eradication vaccination?

A 62-year-old male patient comes with complaints of slowness of speech, and pill-rolling tremors at rest. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) would most likely show changes in which of the following structures?

What would be the most appropriate American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) grade for this patient?
